results.title: [Royal Visit, Victoria, 1954: Pre-Release Footage: Reel 3]
results.brief_description:
The 1954 visit to Australia of newly-crowned Queen Elizabeth II with her husband and consort Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, was a cause of much celebration - and an occasion for much pageantry - in Victoria. Elizabeth was the first reigning monarch to visit Australia, and the young and popular royal couple attracted intense interest wherever they visited on their extensive Australian tour.

This silent, pre-release footage - much of which eventually comprised sections of the official Victorian film release - follows the visiting couple on their journey throughout the state; including numerous regional centres as well as major sites and events in Melbourne. It shows not only the “official” portrait of this historic royal visit, but also dwells on the reactions of the Victorian people; crowds of whom waited by roadsides and railways, on city streets and in small country towns, for a glimpse of the monarch.

As well as focusing on the history of the 1954 royal visit, the footage thus also gives us a unique and invaluable look back in time at some of the buildings, streetscapes, vehicles, cameras, fashions and crowd behaviours of the mid-1950s in Victoria.

Reel 3 focuses on the day the Queen and Duke arrived in Melbourne, and consists mainly of short sections of footage, much of which is also seen in other Reels of this Collection.

Detailed Description Reel 3:

Opens with aerial view of motorcade at top of Bourke Street, Melbourne, (probably leaving Parliament House). At 00:00:11:00 footage switches to Essendon Airport, with officials and police arriving in car and on motorbikes: 00:00:31:00 Crowds are seen waiting for the Queen’s arrival. 00:00:41:00 Arrival of Victorian Governor Sir Dallas Brooks. 00:00:50:00 Flinders Naval Depot Band. 00:01:07:00 footage of crowds along streets from moving car. 00:01:12:00 Queen and Duke walking across tarmac at Essendon Airport. 00:01:20:00 photographers filming the crowds from a moving car. 00:01:24:00 back at Essendon Airport, assembled sailors. 00:01:30:00 close-ups of various officials at, and leaving, Airport. 00:02:25:00 Queen and Duke exiting aeroplane. 00:02:34:00 Queen and Duke reviewing assembled sailors. 00:02:55:00 Queen and Duke in car beginning to leave airport, crowds running to view car. 00:03:07:00 close-up of luggage. 00:03:10:00 staff exiting plane. 00:03:35:00 drive past Essendon Town Hall with crowds on balcony of Town Hall and lining streets. 00:04:00:00 Crowds in street. 00:04:11:00 Queen and Duke on dais, Mayor making a speech. 00:05:08:00 street scene (probably in Essendon), with large crowd in process of dispersing. 00:05:18:00 cars leaving Essendon Town Hall. 00:05:35:00 crowd on steps of State Parliament shot from moving car. 00:05:51:00 crowds behind barriers lining CBD streets. 00:06:12:00 close-up of Henry Bolte, then leader of the Opposition Victorian Liberal Party, on street outside Parliament House. 00:06:27:00 close-up of Queen and Duke getting into car. 00:06:54:00 close-up of people in crowd with spires of St Patrick’s Cathedral in background. 00:07:37:00 State Parliament building, assembled police. 00:07:41:00 people watching from the top of the Imperial Hotel (still extant on the corner Bourke and Spring Streets, Melbourne), and a “Molina’s” sign can be seen (indicating Melbourne’s famous Molina’s Cafe). 00:07:49:00 close-up of workman affixing red carpet to steps of State Parliament; as a stray dog wanders past. 00:07:54:00 Queen’s car approaching State Parliament, crowds outside Parliament building. 00:08:50:00 a man vacuums the red-carpet laid outside Parliament building. 00:09:35:00 Queen and Duke exiting their car outside State Parliament. 00:10:00:00 the Victorian parliamentary Mace and Black Rod are carried up the steps of State Parliament, with Queen and Duke following. 00:10:38:00 Mace and Black Rod are carried down the steps again.

as a stray dog wanders past. 00:07:54:00 Queen’s car approaching State Parliament, crowds outside Parliament building. 00:08:50:00 a man vacuums the red-carpet laid outside Parliament building. 00:09:35:00 Queen and Duke exiting their car outside State Parliament. 00:10:00:00 the Victorian parliamentary Mace and Black Rod are carried up the steps of State Parliament, with Queen and Duke following. 00:10:38:00 Mace and Black Rod are carried down the steps again.

results.title: [Royal Visit, Victoria, 1954: Pre-Release Footage: Reel 2]
results.brief_description:
The 1954 visit to Australia of newly-crowned Queen Elizabeth II with her husband and consort Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, was a cause of much celebration - and an occasion for much pageantry - in Victoria. Elizabeth was the first reigning monarch to visit Australia, and the young and popular royal couple attracted intense interest wherever they visited on their extensive Australian tour.

This silent, pre-release footage - much of which eventually comprised sections of the official Victorian film release - follows the visiting couple on their journey throughout the state; including numerous regional centres as well as major sites and events in Melbourne. It shows not only the “official” portrait of this historic royal visit, but also dwells on the reactions of the Victorian people; crowds of whom waited by roadsides and railways, on city streets and in small country towns, for a glimpse of the monarch.

As well as focusing on the history of the 1954 royal visit, the footage thus also gives us a unique and invaluable look back in time at some of the buildings, streetscapes, vehicles, cameras, fashions and crowd behaviours of the mid-1950s in Victoria.

Reel 2 of the collection dwells on the decorations that celebrated the visit, in the streets and on the buildings of Melbourne’s CBD, then shows the officials and staff responsible for the planning and conduct of the tour at work inside the (now demolished) Geological Museum. We are shown the Victorian police reinforcements arranged for the visit being addressed by their commanders, before the scene shifts to Essendon Airport and the preparations for touchdown of the ‘royal’ plane.

Detailed Description Reel 2:

Opens with Title “Melbourne: City decorations”, followed by footage of Melbourne CBD streets and buildings sporting decorations for the visit (Flinders Street Railway Station from Elizabeth Street, Myer Emporium, Swanston Street, the Leviathan Building, trams and cars). 00:00:54:00 shot of old Princes Bridge Railway Station (partially obscured). 00:01:15:00 The Commercial Bank of Australia. 00:01:25:00 decorated Melbourne Town Hall. 00:01:31:0 Foy and Gibson building. 00:01:35:00 emu and kangaroo diorama. 00:01:59:0 Title “Royal Visit Offices: Geological Museum” followed by footage of the exterior of the (now demolished) building in Macarthur Street, and scenes of the staff at work inside. 00:03:32:00 Title “Police Re-Inforcements: The Chief Commissioner and the Chief Secretary address 750 men prior to the visit.” followed by footage of uniformed police being addressed by the commanders. 00:04:25:00 Title “Official Landing & Reception: Melbourne Airport - Overseas Terminal Wednesday, 24th. February, 1954” followed by footage of preparations for the arrival, men in top-hats, men in uniform and waiting crowd. 00:05:12:00 Flinders Naval Depot Band. 00:05:36:00 arrival and close-up of Victorian Governor Sir Dallas Brooks as he exits car. 00:05:44:00 Flinders Naval Depot Band and sailors marching. 00:06:04:00 plane taxis onto tarmac, close-up of royal coat of arms on plane, which is flying the Royal Standard. Camera pans across “Australian National Airways Pty Ltd - Royal Mail” written on side of plane. Exit stairs are wheeled up to plane, and the Queen and Duke step out.

results.title: [Royal Visit, Victoria, 1954: Pre-Release Footage: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
The 1954 visit to Australia of newly-crowned Queen Elizabeth II with her husband and consort Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, was a cause of much celebration - and an occasion for much pageantry - in Victoria. Elizabeth was the first reigning monarch to visit Australia, and the young and popular royal couple attracted intense interest wherever they visited on their extensive Australian tour.

This silent, pre-release footage - much of which eventually comprised sections of the official Victorian film release - follows the visiting couple on their journey throughout the state; including numerous regional centres as well as major sites and events in Melbourne. It shows not only the “official” portrait of this historic royal visit, but also dwells on the reactions of the Victorian people; crowds of whom waited by roadsides and railways, on city streets and in small country towns, for a glimpse of the monarch.

As well as focusing on the history of the 1954 royal visit, the footage thus also gives us a unique and invaluable look back in time at some of the buildings, streetscapes, vehicles, cameras, fashions and crowd behaviours of the mid-1950s in Victoria.

Reel 1 of this extraordinary collection corresponds to the first 11 minutes of the official State Film Centre release (see ACMI Collection Title [315392]) “The Visit to Victoria of Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II and His Royal Highness the Duke of Edinburgh”. It shows some of the preparations for the visit, the arrival by plane of the royal couple at Essendon Airport and their first progress through Melbourne to State Parliament and Government House. We see the Queen opening State Parliament, visiting the MCG to meet with Australian armed servicemen and women, attending a special race meeting at Flemington Racecourse and a Davis Cup game at Kooyong Tennis Centre. The Queen and Duke also go to St Paul’s Cathedral, and the reel closes with the official dedication of the forecourt and eternal flame at Melbourne’s Shrine of Remembrance.

Detailed Description Reel 1:

Opens with Titles:
1) “The State Film Centre Presents”
2) “The Visit to Victoria of Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth the Second and His Royal Highness the Duke of Edinburgh”
3) “Filmed with the co-operation of State Government Departments, Cine Service Pty. Ltd., and The Films Advisory Bureau”
00:00:42:00. Followed by shot of exterior of Geological Museum (this building at 55 McArthur St East Melbourne, used as the Government offices for the Royal Visit; was demolished 1964), and footage of the State Director and staff at work.
00:00:59:00 footage of street scenes and close-ups of decorated buildings in Melbourne CBD (moving diorama of kangaroo and emu above The Myer Emporium 00:01:09:0 to 00:01:16:0).
00:01:27 Essendon Airport awaiting the arrival of the royal visitors.
00:01:38:00 close up of then Governor Dallas Brooks; John Cain Snr (then Premier) also present.
00:01:40:00 Flinders Naval Depot Band.
00:01:50:00 plane lands.
00:02:03:00 Queen & Duke exit plane and are greeted by Governor and Premier on tarmac.
00:02:23:00 Queen reviews guard of honour provided by troops from Royal Australian Navy.
00:02:39:00 Queen & Duke are introduced to a succession of “leading citizens”.
00:03:02:00 car begins departure from airport, and drives through crowd-lined streets.
00:03:24:00 car arrives at Parliament House, Melbourne, where a crowd fills the front steps.
00:03:33:00 Queen and Duke stand halfway up steps and are flanked by Victorian Parliamentary Mace and Black Rod (probably being held by Serjeant-at-Arms and Usher of the Black Rod).
00:03:40:00 Royal Salute - 4 gun artillery salute fired in Domain.
00:03:42:00 Queen and Duke descend steps of Parliament House, Melbourne.
00:03:46:00 drives through crowd-lined streets of Melbourne CBD, with Queen & Duke waving and smiling at crowds.
00:03:52:00 aerial shot of Collins Street at Spring Street end.
00:04:24:00 aerial shot of corner of Swanston and Flinders Streets (site of future Gas and Fuel buildings and Federation Square).
00:04:27:00 an aerial shot looking back to CBD from St Kilda Rd; Flinders St Station and St Paul’s Cathedral can be identified.
00:04:31:00 aerial distance shot of Government House, Melbourne.
00:04:42:00 car arrives at Government House.
00:05:04:00 shot of Royal Standard flying over Government House (only flown when monarch in residence).
00:05:08 night scenes of Melbourne CBD decorations.
00:05:28:00 night scenes of fireworks.
00:05:36:00 Queen & Duke taking places at opening of Victorian Parliament; footage inside Legislative Council chamber, Queen in state dress and Order of Garter (Duke in uniform).
00:07:42:00 the M.C.G, and an assembly of ex-servicemen and women.
00:08:02:00 shot of airplane in mid-air. 00:08:08:00 children waving flags in crowd.
00:08:13:00 close-up of Queen making speech (into microphone).
00:08:18:00 close-up of technicians broadcasting the speech.
00:08:24:00 Flemington Racecourse, aerial shot of crowd and betting gates.
00:08:36:00 Queen & Dukes’ car arrives, driving down middle of course.
00:08:52:00 horses in saddling paddock. 00:09:01:00 horses racing.
00:09:17:00 Queen presents cup to winning owner & talks to winning jockey.
00:09:25:00 Queen takes her seat in the stands at Kooyong Tennis Centre.
00:09:32:00 tennis being played.
00:09:44:00 shot of film camera operators (possibly filming newsreel footage?).
00:09:46:00 a presentation is made to Queen on the court.
00:09:51:00 shot of exterior of St Paul’s Cathedral (Melbourne), Queen & Duke walk down steps with Archbishop of Melbourne (Joseph Booth).
00:10:02:00 aerial shots of car driving through Melbourne streets.
00:10:05:00 aerial view of Shrine of Remembrance.
00:10:09:00 close-up of Queen making speech at microphone.
00:10:29:00 close-up of Duke listening to speech.
00:10:36:00 aerial shots of listening crowd.
00:11:24:00 Queen pushes some mechanism near microphone, and the Shrine’s eternal flame is seen smoking (as the Queen has just lighted it.)

Opens with Titles:

00:00:42:00. Followed by shot of exterior of Geological Museum (this building at 55 McArthur St East Melbourne, used as the Government offices for the Royal Visit; was demolished 1964), and footage of the State Director and staff at work.
00:00:59:00 footage of street scenes and close-ups of decorated buildings in Melbourne CBD (moving diorama of kangaroo and emu above The Myer Emporium 00:01:09:0 to 00:01:16:0).
00:01:27 Essendon Airport awaiting the arrival of the royal visitors.
00:01:38:00 close up of then Governor Dallas Brooks; John Cain Snr (then Premier) also present.
00:01:40:00 Flinders Naval Depot Band.
00:01:50:00 plane lands.
00:02:03:00 Queen & Duke exit plane and are greeted by Governor and Premier on tarmac.
00:02:23:00 Queen reviews guard of honour provided by troops from Royal Australian Navy.
00:02:39:00 Queen & Duke are introduced to a succession of “leading citizens”.
00:03:02:00 car begins departure from airport, and drives through crowd-lined streets.
00:03:24:00 car arrives at Parliament House, Melbourne, where a crowd fills the front steps.
00:03:33:00 Queen and Duke stand halfway up steps and are flanked by Victorian Parliamentary Mace and Black Rod (probably being held by Serjeant-at-Arms and Usher of the Black Rod).
00:03:40:00 Royal Salute - 4 gun artillery salute fired in Domain.
00:03:42:00 Queen and Duke descend steps of Parliament House, Melbourne.
00:03:46:00 drives through crowd-lined streets of Melbourne CBD, with Queen & Duke waving and smiling at crowds.
00:03:52:00 aerial shot of Collins Street at Spring Street end.
00:04:24:00 aerial shot of corner of Swanston and Flinders Streets (site of future Gas and Fuel buildings and Federation Square).
00:04:27:00 an aerial shot looking back to CBD from St Kilda Rd; Flinders St Station and St Paul’s Cathedral can be identified.
00:04:31:00 aerial distance shot of Government House, Melbourne.
00:04:42:00 car arrives at Government House.
00:05:04:00 shot of Royal Standard flying over Government House (only flown when monarch in residence).
00:05:08 night scenes of Melbourne CBD decorations.
00:05:28:00 night scenes of fireworks.
00:05:36:00 Queen & Duke taking places at opening of Victorian Parliament; footage inside Legislative Council chamber, Queen in state dress and Order of Garter (Duke in uniform).
00:07:42:00 the M.C.G, and an assembly of ex-servicemen and women.
00:08:02:00 shot of airplane in mid-air. 00:08:08:00 children waving flags in crowd.
00:08:13:00 close-up of Queen making speech (into microphone).
00:08:18:00 close-up of technicians broadcasting the speech.
00:08:24:00 Flemington Racecourse, aerial shot of crowd and betting gates.
00:08:36:00 Queen & Dukes’ car arrives, driving down middle of course.
00:08:52:00 horses in saddling paddock. 00:09:01:00 horses racing.
00:09:17:00 Queen presents cup to winning owner & talks to winning jockey.
00:09:25:00 Queen takes her seat in the stands at Kooyong Tennis Centre.
00:09:32:00 tennis being played.
00:09:44:00 shot of film camera operators (possibly filming newsreel footage?).
00:09:46:00 a presentation is made to Queen on the court.
00:09:51:00 shot of exterior of St Paul’s Cathedral (Melbourne), Queen & Duke walk down steps with Archbishop of Melbourne (Joseph Booth).
00:10:02:00 aerial shots of car driving through Melbourne streets.
00:10:05:00 aerial view of Shrine of Remembrance.
00:10:09:00 close-up of Queen making speech at microphone.
00:10:29:00 close-up of Duke listening to speech.
00:10:36:00 aerial shots of listening crowd.
00:11:24:00 Queen pushes some mechanism near microphone, and the Shrine’s eternal flame is seen smoking (as the Queen has just lighted it.)
description_for_label:
The 1954 visit to Australia of newly-crowned Queen Elizabeth II with her husband and consort Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, was a cause of much celebration - and an occasion for much pageantry - in Victoria. Elizabeth was the first reigning monarch to visit Australia, and the young and popular royal couple attracted intense interest wherever they visited on their extensive Australian tour.

This silent, pre-release footage - much of which eventually comprised sections of the official Victorian film release - follows the visiting couple on their journey throughout the state; including numerous regional centres as well as major sites and events in Melbourne. It shows not only the “official” portrait of this historic royal visit, but also dwells on the reactions of the Victorian people; crowds of whom waited by roadsides and railways, on city streets and in small country towns, for a glimpse of the monarch.

As well as focusing on the history of the 1954 royal visit, the footage thus also gives us a unique and invaluable look back in time at some of the buildings, streetscapes, vehicles, cameras, fashions and crowd behaviours of the mid-1950s in Victoria.

Reel 1 of this extraordinary collection corresponds to the first 11 minutes of the official State Film Centre release (see ACMI Collection Title [315392]) “The Visit to Victoria of Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II and His Royal Highness the Duke of Edinburgh”. It shows some of the preparations for the visit, the arrival by plane of the royal couple at Essendon Airport and their first progress through Melbourne to State Parliament and Government House. We see the Queen opening State Parliament, visiting the MCG to meet with Australian armed servicemen and women, attending a special race meeting at Flemington Racecourse and a Davis Cup game at Kooyong Tennis Centre. The Queen and Duke also go to St Paul’s Cathedral, and the reel closes with the official dedication of the forecourt and eternal flame at Melbourne’s Shrine of Remembrance.

Detailed Description Reel 1:

Opens with Titles:
1) “The State Film Centre Presents”
2) “The Visit to Victoria of Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth the Second and His Royal Highness the Duke of Edinburgh”
3) “Filmed with the co-operation of State Government Departments, Cine Service Pty. Ltd., and The Films Advisory Bureau”
00:00:42:00. Followed by shot of exterior of Geological Museum (this building at 55 McArthur St East Melbourne, used as the Government offices for the Royal Visit; was demolished 1964), and footage of the State Director and staff at work.
00:00:59:00 footage of street scenes and close-ups of decorated buildings in Melbourne CBD (moving diorama of kangaroo and emu above The Myer Emporium 00:01:09:0 to 00:01:16:0).
00:01:27 Essendon Airport awaiting the arrival of the royal visitors.
00:01:38:00 close up of then Governor Dallas Brooks; John Cain Snr (then Premier) also present.
00:01:40:00 Flinders Naval Depot Band.
00:01:50:00 plane lands.

00:04:24:00 aerial shot of corner of Swanston and Flinders Streets (site of future Gas and Fuel buildings and Federation Square).
00:04:27:00 an aerial shot looking back to CBD from St Kilda Rd; Flinders St Station and St Paul’s Cathedral can be identified.
00:04:31:00 aerial distance shot of Government House, Melbourne.
00:04:42:00 car arrives at Government House.
00:05:04:00 shot of Royal Standard flying over Government House (only flown when monarch in residence).
00:05:08 night scenes of Melbourne CBD decorations.
00:05:28:00 night scenes of fireworks.
00:05:36:00 Queen & Duke taking places at opening of Victorian Parliament; footage inside Legislative Council chamber, Queen in state dress and Order of Garter (Duke in uniform).
00:07:42:00 the M.C.G, and an assembly of ex-servicemen and women.

00:08:18:00 close-up of technicians broadcasting the speech.

00:08:36:00 Queen & Dukes’ car arrives, driving down middle of course.
00:08:52:00 horses in saddling paddock. 00:09:01:00 horses racing.

results.title: [Raymond Penington Home Movies: Reel 3]
results.brief_description:
The Raymond Penington Home Movie Collection is a collection of 16mm colour and black-and-white films made between 1938 and 1965. Dr. Raymond Penington (born 1903) was a medical doctor from Melbourne, Victoria. He and his wife Edith lived in Papua New Guinea in the late 1920s before returning to Melbourne in 1931 and settling in Canterbury. They had three children, Margaret, Vivienne and Jocelyn. His home movies focus on family life in Melbourne and holidays in regional Victoria.

Travelling between Port Campbell in Victoria and South Australia’s Port McDonnell, this film follows the Penington family’s trip along the West Victorian coastline.

Included are the Port Campbell cliffs, Great Ocean Road’s ‘The Blow Hole’, ‘Loch Ard Gorge’ and ‘London Bridge’ (now known as the London Arch and the Twelve Apostles).

Other places visited include Warrnambool, Port Fairy, Portland, Mt Gambier, Port McDonnell (SA) and Cape Nelson.

The film shows a number of vehicles from the 1950s and fashion from the time; however, the majority of the film is scenery.

Buildings of interest include the Fletcher Jones Plus 8 building and Gardens in Warrnambool, ‘Hotel Richmond, The original home of the Henty’s’ and Custom House, Port McDonnell.

The film finishes with a semi-fade to black shot of the back of the Penington family caravan and title card ‘The End’.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:06:00 Port Campbell, sea cliffs, Sherbrook River and the Twelve apostles
00:06:13:00 Warrnambool Welcome Sign
00:07:56:00 FJ Plus 8 industries - Fletcher Jones Garden, Warrnambool
00:09:49:00 Margaret and Ray Penington on the Rocks looking out to sea, Port Fairy
00:12:20:00 Margaret, Vivienne and Jocelyn Penington on the docks, Portland
00:12:41:00 long shot looking along Henty Street out to sea with the All Saints Catholic Church in view and old 50s cars can be seen driving along it
00:13:03:00 Pennington girls greeting each other on either side of the south Australian Border Sign
00:13:56:00 scenes of Brown, Valley and Blue Lakes, Mt Gambier
00:16:35:00 rook wall and Lookout (Built in 1918), Mt Gambier
00:19:51:00 scenes of the Penington women walking through Cape Nelson Park

results.title: [Raymond Penington Home Movies: Reel 2]
results.brief_description:
The Raymond Penington Home Movie Collection is a collection of 16mm colour and black-and-white films made between 1938 and 1965. Dr. Raymond Penington (born 1903) was a medical doctor from Melbourne, Victoria. He and his wife Edith lived in Papua New Guinea in the late 1920s before returning to Melbourne in 1931 and settling in Canterbury. They had three children, Margaret, Vivienne and Jocelyn. His home movies focus on family life in Melbourne and holidays in regional Victoria.

This film is set at the Grampians, Victoria. It begins at Halls Gap Caravan park and then continues with highlights of the Grampians including Coronation Chair, Ladies Hat, The Jaws of Death and The Pinnacle.

Each scene has been meticulously titled to indicate the whereabouts within the Grampians.

There is a scene of the original shopping strip and Taylor’s Store and Café and a few old cars of the era and earlier can be seen.

Towards the end of the film is a number of beautiful images of fauna and flora of the area including the Golden Wattle and Banksia.

At one point you can see the Penington girls practising dissection of a rabbit and a scene of them riding horses.

The film ends with the title “And so Home”.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:53:00 Taylor’s Store and Café, Main street, Halls Gap showing old Vintage cars
00:02:32:00 the three Penington girls washing up and doing a rabbit dissection
00:03:23:00 Penington Family sitting in the trees reading
00:05:02:00 Penington family on Mount Victory and the views from the rock
00:05:31:00 Jaws of Death, Grampians
00:06:19:00 Coronation Chair
00:08:31:00 eldest Penington daughter trying to do a flying pose in front of McKenzie falls
00:10:28:00 scenes of rock formation, Grand Canyon
00:12:30:00 Ladies Hat. rock formation
00:14:28:00 flora and fauna from the Grampian area
00:20:07:00 eldest Penington girls holding dead rabbits

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 15]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker who was particularly keen on capturing the Australian landscape from the 1960s to the 1990s. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film is made up of two films. The first captures the dramatic coastline of the ‘Shipwreck Coast’ in the west of Victoria. It also features the ‘Fletcher Jones’ (clothing manufacturers) at Warrnambool including the ‘Silver Ball’ water tower designed by Ralph Jones, engineer and eldest son of owner David Fletcher Jones. Erected in 1967 as part of the Pleasant Hill factory’s extensive fire protection system, the water tower was state heritage listed, along with other aspects of the Pleasant Hill site, in August 2006.

The second film features Victorian National parks.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 title ‘Coastal Panarama’ and ‘A WHC Film’
00:00:23:00 roadsign ‘Port Campbell National Park’ followed by views from the ocean cliffs including the Twelve Apostles
00:01:52:00 an old grave with an engraved headstone for members of the Carmichael family followed by dramatic views out over the roiling sea
00:05:46:00 the Fletcher Jones headquarters building in Warrnambool, Victoria
00:05:49:00 the ‘hawkers wagon’ emblazoned with information on history of Fletcher Jones as ‘painstaking tailors’
00:05:55:00 views around the grounds of the Fletcher Jones headquarters
00:06:45:00 old boats and sailing ships in dry dock possibly at Flagstaff Hill maritime museum, Warrnambool
00:07:40:00 the Lady Bay lighthouse at Flastaff Hill in Warrnambool and views of a canon looking out to sea
00:09:17:00 a distinctive rocky outcrop on a beach
00:09:52:00 looking out over the waterways and beaches of Warrnambool from a higher vantage point followed by some caves and grassy paddocks with grazing sheep
00:10:29:00 title card ‘The End’
00:10:50:00 title cards ‘A Walkabout Film’ and ‘National Parks of the S.E.’
00:11:15:00 roadsign ‘Mount Richmond National Park’ follwed by close-ups of wildflowers
00:12:03:00 a car with gear packed on the roofrack
00:12:14:00 sign ‘Discovery Bay Coastal Park National Parks Service’
00:14:40:00 bee-keeping
00:14:49:00 walking up a steep sand dune and down again; views of the dunes and beach; pelicans on the water; views of the sea and beaches
00:15:49:00 fishing and a child runs across the frame in ‘gumboots’
00:15:55:00 sign ‘Lower Glenelg National Park’ and ‘Glenelg River’, a large river or lagoon, wildflowers and sea birds
00:17:08:00 sunset over the sea
00:18:57:00 boathouses and small boats on old jettys
00:19:07:00 sign ‘State Border South Australia’
00:19:35:00 jetty and motor boat
00:19:57:00 farmland with old buildings and a windmill
00:21:01:00 looking out from the rocky shore
00:21:30:00 old entry signs ‘Clarke Park’ followed by ‘Dingley Dell’ which is the historic home of one of Australia’s most famous poets, Adam Lindsay Gordon, and views of the cottage in which he lived

Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film is made up of two films. The first captures the dramatic coastline of the ‘Shipwreck Coast’ in the west of Victoria. It also features the ‘Fletcher Jones’ (clothing manufacturers) at Warrnambool including the ‘Silver Ball’ water tower designed by Ralph Jones, engineer and eldest son of owner David Fletcher Jones. Erected in 1967 as part of the Pleasant Hill factory’s extensive fire protection system, the water tower was state heritage listed, along with other aspects of the Pleasant Hill site, in August 2006.

The second film features Victorian National parks.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 title ‘Coastal Panarama’ and ‘A WHC Film’
00:00:23:00 roadsign ‘Port Campbell National Park’ followed by views from the ocean cliffs including the Twelve Apostles
00:01:52:00 an old grave with an engraved headstone for members of the Carmichael family followed by dramatic views out over the roiling sea
00:05:46:00 the Fletcher Jones headquarters building in Warrnambool, Victoria
00:05:49:00 the ‘hawkers wagon’ emblazoned with information on history of Fletcher Jones as ‘painstaking tailors’
00:05:55:00 views around the grounds of the Fletcher Jones headquarters
00:06:45:00 old boats and sailing ships in dry dock possibly at Flagstaff Hill maritime museum, Warrnambool
00:07:40:00 the Lady Bay lighthouse at Flastaff Hill in Warrnambool and views of a canon looking out to sea
00:09:17:00 a distinctive rocky outcrop on a beach
00:09:52:00 looking out over the waterways and beaches of Warrnambool from a higher vantage point followed by some caves and grassy paddocks with grazing sheep
00:10:29:00 title card ‘The End’
00:10:50:00 title cards ‘A Walkabout Film’ and ‘National Parks of the S.E.’
00:11:15:00 roadsign ‘Mount Richmond National Park’ follwed by close-ups of wildflowers
00:12:03:00 a car with gear packed on the roofrack
00:12:14:00 sign ‘Discovery Bay Coastal Park National Parks Service’
00:14:40:00 bee-keeping
00:14:49:00 walking up a steep sand dune and down again; views of the dunes and beach; pelicans on the water; views of the sea and beaches
00:15:49:00 fishing and a child runs across the frame in ‘gumboots’
00:15:55:00 sign ‘Lower Glenelg National Park’ and ‘Glenelg River’, a large river or lagoon, wildflowers and sea birds
00:17:08:00 sunset over the sea
00:18:57:00 boathouses and small boats on old jettys
00:19:07:00 sign ‘State Border South Australia’
00:19:35:00 jetty and motor boat
00:19:57:00 farmland with old buildings and a windmill
00:21:01:00 looking out from the rocky shore
00:21:30:00 old entry signs ‘Clarke Park’ followed by ‘Dingley Dell’ which is the historic home of one of Australia’s most famous poets, Adam Lindsay Gordon, and views of the cottage in which he lived
description_for_label:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker who was particularly keen on capturing the Australian landscape from the 1960s to the 1990s. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film is made up of two films. The first captures the dramatic coastline of the ‘Shipwreck Coast’ in the west of Victoria. It also features the ‘Fletcher Jones’ (clothing manufacturers) at Warrnambool including the ‘Silver Ball’ water tower designed by Ralph Jones, engineer and eldest son of owner David Fletcher Jones. Erected in 1967 as part of the Pleasant Hill factory’s extensive fire protection system, the water tower was state heritage listed, along with other aspects of the Pleasant Hill site, in August 2006.

The second film features Victorian National parks.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.
